correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is indicated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for future entry subsections.

list.item: Encoding uses the recommendations for Level 3 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines.
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Running headers and side descriptions are not included.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, small caps, strike-through, subscript, superscript, underline. The following formatting is ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze.
Subject-level metadata was added to each entry using the HIVE automated vocabulary server created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: The first release is a reproduction of text matter for all entries. It does not include images, tables, formulae, front- or back-matter. It omits volume 1, which consists of "Dissertations" rather than entries.

prefixDef.p: URIs with the prefix fast: point to terms in the OCLC FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology) subject heading schema derived from the Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH).
URIs with the prefix lcsh1910: point to subject terms in the volume Subject Headings Used in the Dictionary Catalogues of the Library of Congress, 7 vols., Library of Congress, 1910.
URIs with the prefix ht: point to page images in the Hathi Trust.
URIs with the prefix ia: point to page images in the Internet Archive.
URIs with the prefix nls: point to page images in the National Library of Scotland.

div.p:
SCOTER, a word of doubtful origin, perhaps a variant of “Scout,” one of the many local names shared in common by the Guillemot (vol. xi. p. 262) and the Razorbill (vol. XX. p. 302), or perhaps primarily connected with Coot (vol. vi. p. 341),
In the former case the derivation seems to be from the O. Fr. Escoute, and that from the Latin auscultare (comp. Skeat, Etymol. Dictionary, p. 533), but in the latter from the Dutch Koet, which is said to be of Celtic extraction— cwtiar (op. cit., p. 134). The French Macreuse, possibly from the Latin macer, indicating a bird that may be eaten in Lent or on the fast days of the Roman Church, is of double signification, meaning in the south of France a Coot and in the north a Scoter. By the wild-fowlers of parts of North America Scoters are commonly called Coots. the English name of the Anas nigra of Linnaeus, which with some allied species has been justifiably placed in a distinct genus, Oedemia (often misspelt Oidemia) —a name coined in reference to the swollen appearance of the base of the bill. The Scoter is also very generally known around the British coasts as the “Black Duck” from the male being, with the exception of a stripe of orange that runs down the ridge of the bill, wholly of that colour. In the representative American form, Oe. americana, the protuberance at the base of the bill, black in the European bird, is orange as well. Of all Ducks the Scoter has the most marine habits, keeping the sea in all weathers, and rarely resorting to land except for the purpose of breeding. Even in summer small flocks of Scoters may generally be seen in the tideway at the mouth of any of the larger British rivers or in mid-channel, while in autumn and winter these flocks are so increased as to number thousands of individuals, and the water often looks black with them. A second species, the Velvet-Duck, Oe. fusca, of much larger size, distinguished by a white spot under each eye and a white bar on each wing, is far less abundant than the former, but examples of it are occasionally to be seen in company with the commoner one, and it too has its American counterpart, Oe. vel·vetina; while a third, only known as a straggler to Europe, the Surf-Duck, Oe. perspicillata, with a white patch on the crown and another on the nape, and a curiously particoloured bill, is a not uncommon bird in North-American waters. All the species of Oedemia, like most other Sea-Ducks, have their true home in arctic or subarctic countries, but the Scoter itself is said to breed occasionally in Scotland (Zoologist, s.s. p. 1867). The females display little of the deep sable hue that characterizes their partners, but are attired in soot-colour, varied, especially beneath, with brownish white. The flesh of all these birds has an exceedingly strong taste, and, after much controversy, was allowed by the authorities to rank as fish in the ecclesiastical dietary (cf. Graindorge, Traité de Vorigine des Macreuses, Caen, 1680; and Correspondence of John Ray, Ray Soc. ed., p. 148).
